title: Anaphylaxis
p0: If you're with someone having an allergic reaction with signs of anaphylaxis :
p1: -> Immediately call 911 or your local medical emergency number .
p2: -> Ask the person if he or she is carrying an epinephrine autoinjector (EpiPen, Auvi-Q, others) to treat an allergic attack .
p3: -> If the person says he or she needs to use an autoinjector, ask whether you should help inject the medication. This is usually done by pressing the autoinjector against the person's thigh.
p4: -> Have the person lie still on his or her back.
p5: -> Loosen tight clothing and cover the person with a blanket. Don't give the person anything to drink.
p6: -> If there's vomiting or bleeding from the mouth, turn the person on his or her side to prevent choking.

title: Animal bites
p0: These guidelines can help you care for a minor animal bite, such as one that only breaks the skin:
p1: -> Wash the wound thoroughly with soap and water.
p2: -> Apply an antibiotic cream and cover the bite with a clean bandage.
p4: -> The wound is a deep puncture or you're not sure how serious it is.
p5: -> The skin is badly torn, crushed or bleeding significantly — first apply pressure with a bandage or clean cloth to stop the bleeding.
p6: -> You notice increasing swelling, redness, pain or oozing, which are warning signs of infection.

title: Black eye
p0: To take care of a black eye:
p1: -> Apply a cold compress soon after the injury :
p2: Using gentle pressure, place a cold pack or a cloth filled with ice to the area around your eye. Take care not to press on the eye itself. Apply cold as soon as possible after the injury to reduce swelling. Repeat several times a day for a day or two.
p4: If you see it in the white or colored parts of the eye, seek urgent care by an eye specialist (ophthalmologist).
p5: -> Seek medical care immediately if you have vision problems (double vision, blurring), severe pain, bruising around both eyes, or bleeding in an eye or from the nose.
p7: This may be helpful after a few days when the swelling has stabilized. Repeat several times a day for a day or two days..

title: Blisters
p0: To relieve blister-related pain, drain the fluid while leaving the overlying skin intact. Here's how:
p1: -> Wash your hands and the blister with soap and warm water.
p3: -> Sterilize a clean, sharp needle by wiping it with rubbing alcohol.
p4: -> Use the needle to puncture the blister. Aim for several spots near the blister's edge. Let the fluid drain, but leave the overlying skin in place.
p5: -> Seek medical care immediately if you have vision problems (double vision, blurring), severe pain, bruising around both eyes, or bleeding in an eye or from the nose.
p6: -> Apply an ointment (Vaseline, Plastibase, other) to the blister and cover it with a nonstick gauze bandage. If a rash appears, stop using the ointment.
p7: -> Change the dressing every day. Apply more ointment and a bandage.

title: Bruise
p0: You can enhance bruise healing with a few simple techniques. Remember RICE, for rest, ice, compress and elevate:
p1: •	Rest the bruised area, if possible.
p2: •	Ice the bruise with an ice pack wrapped in a towel. Leave it in place for 10 to 20 minutes. Repeat several times a day for a day or two as needed.
p3: •	Compress the bruised area if it is swelling, using an elastic bandage. Don't make it too tight.
p5: If your skin isn't broken, you don't need a bandage. Consider taking an over-the-counter pain reliever if needed.
p7: •	Notice very painful swelling in the bruised area
p8: •	Are still experiencing pain three days after a seemingly minor injury

title: Burns
p1: •	  Cool the burn to help soothe the pain. Hold the burned area under cool (not cold) running water for 10 to 15 minutes or until the pain eases. Or apply a clean towel dampened with cool tap water.
p2: •   Remove rings or other tight items from the burned area. Try to do this quickly and gently, before the area swells.
p3: •	   Don't break small blisters (no bigger than your little fingernail). If blisters break, gently clean the area with mild soap and water, apply an antibiotic ointment, and cover it with a nonstick gauze bandage.
p5: Call 911 or emergency medical help for major burns. Until an emergency unit arrives, take these actions:
p6: • 	Protect the burned person from further harm. If you can do so safely, make sure the person you're helping is not in contact with smoldering materials or exposed to smoke or heat. But don't remove burned clothing stuck to the skin.
p7: • 	Check for signs of circulation. Look for breathing, coughing or movement. Begin CPR if needed.
p8: •	Remove jewelry, belts and other restrictive items, especially from around burned areas and the neck. Burned areas swell rapidly.

title: Chemical burns
p0: If you have an immediately recognized chemical burn
p1: • 	Remove the chemical causing the burn while protecting yourself. For dry chemicals, brush off any remaining material. Wear gloves or use a towel or other suitable object, such as a brush.
